sentence.idiomatic: He's coughing all the time lately.
He's always asking these strange questions.
Why do you never eat breakfast?
He threw up all the stuff he ate for breakfast.
I get carsick. Every time I ride in a car I throw up.
She speaks in such a nauseating way, whenever I hear her I just want to throw up.
I like to lie on my bed, surfing the net and eating.
Lie down and I'll look you over.
If you're not feeling so great, just lie down on the sofa and rest.
There's something I have to do next week, so I'd like to ask for leave.
The company has been pretty busy lately. The boss isn't letting anybody take leave.
I've asked for a month of leave. We can go traveling and have fun.
He took the customer to visit the factory.
In the afternoon I need to take my kid to the playground.
I don't feel like eating alone. Would you mind eating with me?
He's just too thick, you talked to him for so long and still he doesn't get it.
I don't like dummies.
He's zoned out again. I walked over and stood in front of him and he didn't even know.
What's wrong?
It's nothing.

word.literal: to eat something that upsets your stomach

sentence.idiomatic: Did you eat something that upset your stomach?
No. The past two mornings I keep feeling like I'm going to throw up.
Here, drink some water, and lie down a bit longer. Do you want to go to the hospital?
No need to. Get a bag of preserved plums for me. They're just over there.
Oh. Don't go to work today, you need to stay at home and rest up.
I'm not sick. I just feel nauseous. I want to eat something sour.
If it's been going on so long, that's not good. You had better go to the hospital. I'll ask for leave, and take you there.
I'm not sick. How come you're so thick?
What the heck?
I'm pregnant!
Huh?

word.literal: to eat something that upsets your stomach
